metadata.case_number: Appeals by special leave against I.T.A. Nos. 3489, 3490 and 3491 of 1952-53

facts.text: The appellant carries on business in arrack. He also runs a lorry.
For the assessment year 1945-46, the Income-tax Officer found that the income chargeable to tax was Rs. 54,600.
For the assessment year 1946-47, the Income-tax Officer found that the income chargeable was Rs. 27,500.
For the assessment year 1947-48, the Income-tax Officer held that the income chargeable was Rs. 54,500.
These amounts appear in the account books of a firm of which the appellant is a partner as credits from him.

Appellant's explanation: His father had made profits of about Rs. 80,000 in the arrack business conducted by him, had this amount when he died in 1936, entrusted it to the assessee's aunt prior to death, she died in 1944 and handed it over to the appellant before her death.

As regards the balance of about Rs. 42,000, the explanation of the appellant was that they represented the profits earned in a partnership concern which carried on business in arrack during the years 1938-39 to 1944-45. The partners were Ediga Thayappa and M. Govindaswamy Mudaliar. Ediga Thayappa was only a benamidar for the appellant.
This story was rejected by the Income-tax Officer. Both explanations rejected, amounts held to represent concealed income and tax imposed thereon.
Appellant appealed to the Appellate Assistant Commissioner who agreed with the conclusions of the Income-tax Officer.
Appellate Tribunal by judgment dated January 29, 1953 confirmed the decision. Rejected gift story as untrue after examining evidence.
Tribunal held no thing to establish Ediga Thayappa was benamidar; in account books only Thayappa's name; firm registered under section 26A with only Thayappa as partner.
During six years, no proof that Thayappa paid over any share of profits to assessee; Thayappa not remunerated.
Tribunal rejected evidence of Ediga Narashiah and Govindaswamy Mudaliar examined by appellant.
Against Tribunal order, appellant applied for reference to High Court under section 66(2), dismissed by High Court. No appeal against that.
Present appeals by special leave under Article 136 against Tribunal decision.

legal_issues.text: Assuming appellant failed to establish his explanations, does it follow that the amounts were income received or accrued during the previous year? Was it duty of Department to adduce evidence to show source and why treated as concealed income?
Whether Tribunal's finding that amounts are undisclosed income is warranted, or is there ground for interference by Supreme Court?

petitioner_arguments.text: Even if explanations failed, it does not follow as matter of law that amounts were income of previous year; duty of Department to adduce evidence of source and why concealed income. In absence, finding erroneous.
All points urged were taken in reference under s.66(2).

court_reasoning.text: Whether receipt is income depends on facts and circumstances. Here receipts shown in firm books where appellant partner. Called to explain, put forward two explanations rejected. Open to ITO to hold concealed income.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Ample authority: where assessee fails to prove source and nature of cash received, ITO entitled to infer assessable.

court_reasoning.text: Tribunal conclusion amply warranted by facts. No ground for interference.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Dhakeswari allows appeal under Art.136 against Tribunal, but here appellant moved HC under s.66(2), adverse final decision, points not open.

holdings.text: Failure to prove source allows inference of assessable concealed income.
No interference with Tribunal finding; appeals dismissed.

precedents_cited.case_name: Dhakeswari Cotton Mills Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income-tax, West Bengal
precedents_cited.relevance: Holds that appeal under Article 136 possible against Tribunal decision, but inapplicable here due to final adverse HC order on s.66(2) reference.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Income-tax Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Firm registration under 26A showed only Thayappa as partner; reference application to HC under 66(2) dismissed.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Basis for special leave appeals against Tribunal.

outcome.summary: Appeals dismissed with costs. Tribunal's holding that amounts are undisclosed income confirmed; no interference warranted.

key_quotes.text: When both these explanations were rejected, as they have been it was clearly open to the Income-tax Officer to hold that the income must be concealed income.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core reasoning on inference from rejected explanations.

key_quotes.text: There is ample authority for the position that where an assessee fails to prove satisfactorily the source and nature of certain amount of cash received during the accounting year, the Income-tax Officer is entitled to draw the inference that the receipts are of an assessable nature.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Legal principle applied to uphold Tribunal.
